symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests

diagnoses.name: Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV) Infection
diagnoses.rationale: HIV can lead to a wide range of symptoms due to its impact on the immune system. It can cause gastroparesis by affecting the autonomic nerves, lead to dyspnea without directly impairing pulmonary function tests, cause warts due to weakened immune response to human papillomavirus (HPV), pseudoseizures related to stress or neurological complications, and lymphadenopathy as a sign of chronic immune activation.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.rationale: SLE is a chronic autoimmune disease that can affect any part of the body, including the nervous system (contributing to pseudoseizures), skin (leading to warts), the gastrointestinal system (causing gastroparesis), and the lymphatic system (leading to lymphadenopathy). Dyspnea could arise from lupus-related pulmonary issues that might not be detected in standard pulmonary function tests.

diagnoses.name: Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome
diagnoses.rationale: This group of disorders affects connective tissues and can cause diverse symptoms. Gastroparesis might result from connective tissue dysfunction in the gastrointestinal tract, and dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests could be due to chest wall dysregulation. Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome may also indirectly contribute to immunodeficiency, potentially leading to an increase in warts and lymphadenopathy. Pseudoseizures could be related to the broad neurological manifestations of the syndrome.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.rationale: Sarcoidosis is characterized by the growth of tiny collections of inflammatory cells in different parts of the body. It could lead to pulmonary symptoms including dyspnea without obvious findings on pulmonary function tests, lymphadenopathy due to immune system activation, and neurological involvement that might manifest as pseudoseizures. Skin involvement could potentially explain warts. Gastroparesis would be less common but not outside the realm of possibility.

diagnoses.name: Immunodeficiency disorders (Primary or Acquired)
diagnoses.rationale: Primary immunodeficiency disorders or acquired immunodeficiencies beyond HIV could explain this symptom cluster by allowing for opportunistic infections (leading to warts), causing dyspnea (potentially through opportunistic infections not affecting standard pulmonary function tests), and contributing to lymphadenopathy. Neurological manifestations could potentially include pseudoseizures, and some immunodeficiencies could affect stomach motility, leading to gastroparesis.

diagnoses.name: Diabetes Mellitus
diagnoses.rationale: Chronic uncontrolled diabetes can lead to gastroparesis due to vagal nerve damage. While dyspnea with normal pulmonary functions is less directly related, diabetes can exacerbate underlying conditions which could manifest as dyspnea. Diabetes can also impair immune response, leading to an increased risk of warts and potentially lymphadenopathy. Pseudoseizures could occur in the context of hypoglycemic or hyperglycemic episodes.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia (MEN) Type II
diagnoses.rationale: While MEN II is primarily known for its risk of medullary thyroid cancer, pheochromocytoma, and parathyroid tumors, it could indirectly lead to some of the symptoms listed by affecting body systems through hormonal imbalances. Dyspnea, gastroparesis, and possibly lymphadenopathy could be explained, albeit less directly for warts and pseudoseizures.

diagnoses.name: Psychiatric Disorders
diagnoses.rationale: Psychiatric conditions, particularly those involving somatization and functional neurological symptom disorder, could explain pseudoseizures and potentially contribute to perceptions of dyspnea without organic cause. They could indirectly influence other symptoms through neglect of health, leading to secondary conditions such as infections resulting in warts or immune system impact causing lymphadenopathy. Gastroparesis could be influenced by stress-related factors.

diagnoses.name: Lyme Disease
diagnoses.rationale: Chronic Lyme disease can have a myriad of symptoms and is known to affect the nervous system (potentially leading to pseudoseizures), skin (causing an array of dermatological manifestations, potentially including warts), and the immune system (which could explain lymphadenopathy). Gastroparesis and dyspnea might be less directly related but are still within the wide symptomatology reported by some patients.

diagnoses.name: Heavy Metal Poisoning
diagnoses.rationale: Chronic exposure to heavy metals like lead or mercury can lead to a diverse array of symptoms depending on the system affected. Neurological symptoms could explain pseudoseizures, immune system compromise could lead to increased warts and lymphadenopathy, and gastrointestinal system effects could result in gastroparesis. Dyspnea might be more indirectly associated, perhaps through the impact on overall health or specific organ toxicity.

diagnoses.name: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.description: A condition in which your thyroid gland doesn't produce enough of certain crucial hormones, potentially causing hypothermia, fatigue, and decreased appetite.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD)
diagnoses.description: A chronic inflammatory lung disease that causes obstructed airflow from the lungs, leading to symptoms like fatigue and chronic bronchitis.

diagnoses.name: Iron Deficiency Anemia
diagnoses.description: A condition arising from too little iron in the body, leading to fatigue, decreased appetite, and general weakness.

diagnoses.name: Infectious Mononucleosis
diagnoses.description: A viral infection causing fatigue, decreased appetite, and could lead to spleen enlargement presenting risk factors for spleen rupture.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Kidney Disease
diagnoses.description: The gradual loss of kidney function over time can lead to a buildup of waste products in the blood, causing symptoms like fatigue, decreased appetite, and sometimes itching.

diagnoses.name: Heart Failure
diagnoses.description: A chronic condition in which the heart doesn't pump blood as well as it should, can cause fatigue and decreased appetite among other symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Liver Cirrhosis
diagnoses.description: Late stage of scarring (fibrosis) of the liver caused by many forms of liver diseases and conditions, such as hepatitis and chronic alcoholism, can lead to decreased appetite, fatigue, and in some cases itching.

diagnoses.name: Lyme Disease
diagnoses.description: An infectious disease caused by the Borrelia bacterium which is spread by ticks. It can cause fatigue, decreased appetite, and migratory pain that might be confused with pruritus.

diagnoses.name: Malignancy
diagnoses.description: Cancer at various sites can lead to systemic symptoms like decreased appetite, fatigue, possible fever or hypothermia, and in rare cases, paraneoplastic pruritus.

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.description: Human Immunodeficiency Virus affects the immune system and can cause symptoms including fatigue, decreased appetite, chronic bronchitis, and in some cases, pruritus.

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests

diagnoses.name: Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS)
diagnoses.reason: Common cause of infertility; can also contribute to anxiety symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Endometriosis
diagnoses.reason: Can cause infertility and chronic pelvic pain, potentially contributing to conditions like vulvodynia.

diagnoses.name: Primary Ovarian Insufficiency
diagnoses.reason: Linked to infertility and hormonal imbalances, which can exacerbate mood disorders like anxiety.

diagnoses.name: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.reason: Can lead to infertility; symptoms may include anxiety.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Urticaria (for angioedema association)
diagnoses.reason: Chronic hives can be associated with angioedema; chronic conditions can increase anxiety.

diagnoses.name: Hereditary Angioedema
diagnoses.reason: A rare genetic condition causing recurrent episodes of severe swelling. Given its chronic nature, it could lead to or exacerbate anxiety.

diagnoses.name: Anxiety Disorders
diagnoses.reason: Anxiety itself can exacerbate other symptoms or be a primary condition.

diagnoses.name: Fibromyalgia
diagnoses.reason: While not a direct cause of infertility, it's associated with chronic pain conditions like vulvodynia and can be associated with heightened levels of anxiety.

diagnoses.name: Interstitial Cystitis
diagnoses.reason: Associated with chronic pelvic pain similar to vulvodynia and may have a direct or indirect impact on fertility.

diagnoses.name: Autoimmune Disorders
diagnoses.reason: Certain autoimmune conditions can contribute to infertility, chronic pain conditions, and may directly or indirectly mediate angioedema or anxiety symptoms.

diagnoses: Depression (as a secondary condition to chronic illness)
Inflammatory bowel disease (e.g., Crohn's disease, Ulcerative colitis)

diagnoses.name: Migraine
diagnoses.description: A neurological condition characterized by intense headaches often accompanied by nausea, vomiting, and sensitivity to light and sound. In some cases, migraines are preceded by visual disturbances known as auras, which can include scotoma.

diagnoses.name: Meniere's Disease
diagnoses.description: An inner ear disorder that leads to episodes of vertigo (dizziness), tinnitus, hearing loss, and a feeling of fullness in the ear. These episodes can last from minutes to several hours.

diagnoses.name: Benign Paroxysmal Positional Vertigo (BPPV)
diagnoses.description: A disorder arising from a problem in the inner ear. Symptoms include episodes of vertigo with movements such as tilting the head, lying down, or turning over in bed. Nausea can accompany the vertigo.

diagnoses.name: Vestibular Migraine
diagnoses.description: A type of migraine that may or may not cause a headache but includes other symptoms such as severe vertigo, balance problems, nausea, and vomiting. Visual disturbances like scotoma may also occur.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: Abnormal cell growth in the brain can cause headaches, nausea, vomiting, blurred vision or loss of vision, and balance issues. Depending on its location, it might also lead to vertigo.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: An interruption or reduction in the supply of blood to the brain. This condition can result in symptoms such as headaches, difficulty walking, vertigo, nausea, and visual disturbances.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis (MS)
diagnoses.description: An immune-mediated process in which an abnormal response of the body's immune system is directed against the central nervous system. Symptoms can include vertigo, numbness, weakness, balance difficulty, visual disturbances, and sometimes headache.

diagnoses.name: Visual Migraine
diagnoses.description: Similar to a regular migraine but primarily affects vision with symptoms that can include visual phenomena such as scotoma. Headaches, nausea, and light sensitivity may also occur.

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack (TIA)
diagnoses.description: Often called a 'mini-stroke,' a TIA presents symptoms similar to a stroke, including headaches, vertigo, and visual disturbances, but usually lasts only a few minutes without causing permanent damage.

diagnoses.name: Epilepsy
diagnoses.description: A central nervous system disorder in which brain activity becomes abnormal, causing seizures or periods of unusual behavior, and sometimes loss of awareness. Headache, visual disturbances, and nausea can follow a seizure.

diagnoses.name: Migraine with Aura
diagnoses.description: A type of headache characterized by visual disturbances and other aura symptoms followed by a severe headache, often on one side of the head. Symptoms can include nausea, sensitivity to light and sound, scintillation, and sometimes language disturbances like aphasia.

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack (TIA)
diagnoses.description: Often called a mini-stroke, a TIA is a temporary period of symptoms similar to those of a stroke. Symptoms can include headache, dizziness, tinnitus, temporary loss or change of vision (scintillation), and difficulty speaking (aphasia). Unlike a stroke, the symptoms of a TIA usually resolve within minutes to hours and don’t cause permanent damage.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: A stroke occurs when the blood supply to part of the brain is interrupted or reduced, preventing brain tissue from getting oxygen and nutrients. Symptoms can include headache, numbness or paralysis on one side of the body, difficulty speaking (aphasia), and problems seeing.

diagnoses.name: Meningitis
diagnoses.description: An infection of the protective membranes covering the brain and spinal cord. Symptoms can include severe headache, nausea, vomiting, fever, confusion or altered consciousness, and sensitivity to light.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: An abnormal growth of cells within the brain. Symptoms can vary greatly depending on the tumor's location and size but may include headache, nausea, seizures, hearing problems like tinnitus, and vision disturbances.

diagnoses.name: Medication Overuse Headache
diagnoses.description: Headaches arising from the overuse of medication, particularly for headache treatment. It is characterized by frequent or daily headaches with nausea, anxiety, irritability, asthenia, and restlessness.

diagnoses.name: Brain Aneurysm
diagnoses.description: A bulge or ballooning in a blood vessel in the brain. It can leak or rupture, causing bleeding into the brain. Symptoms beforehand may include localized headache, blurred or double vision, and speech changes, including difficulty producing or understanding speech (aphasia).

diagnoses.name: Hypertensive Crisis
diagnoses.description: A severe increase in blood pressure that can lead to stroke. Symptoms may include severe headache, nausea, severe anxiety, shortness of breath, and seizures.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis (MS)
diagnoses.description: A disease in which the immune system eats away at the protective covering of nerves. Symptoms are varied and can include fatigue, walking difficulties, numbness or weakness in one or more limbs, and neuropsychological symptoms, including changes in vision and speech.

diagnoses: Lupus with Central Nervous System Involvement
Viral Infections (such as Epstein-Barr Virus or Cytomegalovirus)
Hepatitis B or C Virus Infection
Infectious diseases (e.g., bacterial sepsis, viral infections like Dengue fever)
Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS)

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease where the body's immune system mistakenly attacks healthy tissue in many parts of the body. Symptoms can include those listed, as lupus can affect the skin, heart, joints, and nervous system.

diagnoses.name: Dermatomyositis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease marked by muscle weakness and a distinctive skin rash. It can affect the skin, causing alopecia, and muscles, leading to myositis. Joint inflammation (synovitis) is also common.

diagnoses.name: Scleroderma
diagnoses.description: A group of autoimmune diseases that cause the skin and connective tissues to harden and tighten. Telangiectasias are common in scleroderma, and the disease can also affect internal organs, potentially leading to symptoms like myelitis.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.description: A chronic inflammatory disorder affecting many joints, including those in the hands and feet. It can lead to synovitis and is associated with extra-articular manifestations like pericardial effusion.

diagnoses.name: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease (MCTD)
diagnoses.description: A rare autoimmune disorder that displays features of several connective tissue diseases such as lupus, scleroderma, and polymyositis, including symptoms like nonscarring alopecia, synovitis, and pericardial effusion.

diagnoses.name: Undifferentiated Connective Tissue Disease (UCTD)
diagnoses.description: Refers to conditions that have symptoms and signs of a connective tissue disease (like lupus or scleroderma) but do not fulfill the criteria for a specific disease. Symptoms can include those mentioned.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease characterized by dry eyes and dry mouth. It can also cause a variety of other symptoms, including skin manifestations like telangiectasias and systemic features such as myelitis.

diagnoses.name: Polymyositis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease causing muscle weakness affecting both sides of the body. It can also involve skin changes and joint problems, though less commonly.

diagnoses.name: Vasculitis
diagnoses.description: A group of disorders that destroy blood vessels by inflammation. Certain types can cause symptoms like those mentioned, including skin changes and nervous system involvement.

diagnoses.name: Behçet's Disease
diagnoses.description: A rare disorder causing blood vessel inflammation throughout your body. The disease can lead to numerous symptoms, including those affecting the skin, joints, and potentially the heart and nervous system.

diagnoses: Hepatitis B or C with Cryoglobulinemia
